subject: Learning
title: Greek Paideia: Educating the Whole Person
description: A fast breakdown of Greek Paideia: Educating the Whole Person for builders.

hook.text: Ancient Greeks didn't just teach subjects. They tried to shape the entire human being.

buildup.text: Paideia meant education of the whole person: mind, body, character, and civic duty.

discovery.text: Athens combined grammar, music, gymnastics, and philosophy into a unified curriculum for citizens.

twist.text: Only free-born males qualified. Women, slaves, and foreigners were excluded from this 'universal' ideal.

climax.text: Still, the concept that education shapes characterâ€”not just skillsâ€”echoes in every liberal arts college today.

punchline.text: The Greeks invented holistic education. They just forgot to include everyone.

quiz.question: What did the Greek concept of paideia aim to develop?
options: The whole person: mind, body, character, and civic duty
